title: Slideshow: Girls’ tennis plays Los Altos on Senior Night
content:
The Palo Alto High School girls' tennis team (7-0) defeated the Los Altos High School Eagles (16-4), 4-3, on senior night. The team will compete in the Central Coast Section (CCS) championship tournament.

<iframe src="https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1vSbAQU6zVVC_niZlQADVfpY55BiRfwJY5GMRxMiMZnU/embed?start=false&loop=false&delayms=3000" width="960" height="569" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>
excerpt: The Palo Alto High School girls' tennis team (7-0) defeated the Los Altos High School Eagles (16-4), 4-3, on senior night. The team will compete in the Central Coast Section (CCS) championship tournament.
author: Ethan Kao

title: Girls’s tennis advances to CCS
content: [caption id="attachment_125083" align="aligncenter" width="620"] Freshman Anuva Banwasi serves the ball in a doubles match with senior captain Meredith Cummings.  The undefeated Vikings went on to win the game 4-3 on senior night. Photo by Ethan Kao.[/caption] The Palo Alto High School girls’ tennis team (12-0) routed Los Altos High School (14-6) 4-3, in an El Camino League match on Tuesday at home. Per tradition, the last home game coincided with senior night. Before the game, parents took photos and gave flowers to the girls. The team's seniors include Cummings, Pearson, Alice Zhang, Brin Elliott, and Mayerly Grace Short. The team’s last regular season win helps seal their undefeated record and finish the season in first place in the ECL, giving them a chance to the Central Coast Section (CCS) championship tournament. Only the top team from the El Camino League gets to compete in the championship tournament, which is predominantly reserved for the De Anza League. The Vikings played in the De Anza League last year before Coach Andy Harader dropped the team down. Buoyed by young talent and solid leadership, the team has enjoyed a breakout season, according to Harader. According to senior doubles player, Avery Pearson, the Vikings won with perseverance. Pearson and her doubles partner, senior Alice Zhang, clinched the deciding match in a game that went to the third set. “Los Altos is a tough team and a lot of the matches went into a third set," Pearson said.  Senior captain Meredith Cummings acknowledged some weakness in today’s game. "Today was a tough match,” Cummings said. "We played well at the baseline overall, but on my court and the others that I could see, our volleys were mainly going into the net. We needed to improve on our net play, as well as moving our feet to the ball.” With the regular season over, the team has shifted its focus to CCS. Cummings feels that a focused exercise regimen will be  a key aspect to winning the championship.  “I have the feeling that if we train hard in practice, eat healthy, and exercise on the weekend, we will be in great shape to try and win it all,” Cummings said. Additionally, Pearson feels the team needs to focus on mental stamina to win.  “To win CCS, I think we all need to be in the right mindset the day of the tournament.  Tennis is a mind game as much as it is a physical sport,” Pearson said. After the undefeated regular season, Harader is confident that the girls can win the league CCS championship.  “The only thing keeping us from winning the championship will be ourselves this season,” Harader said in September — a day before the season started.   [caption id="attachment_125085" align="aligncenter" width="600"] The team's seniors (in the back) line up to take a photo with their younger counterparts on senior night held on Tuesday. Photo by Rachel Code.[/caption]   The team’s first game in the playoff series will come next Tuesday with the date, location, and opponent currently listed as “TBA.”
excerpt: The Palo Alto High School girls’ tennis team (12-0) routed Los Altos High School, 4-3, in an El Camino League match on Tuesday at home.
author: Siddarth Sharma

title: Coffee Chats: Biology teacher Tara Verekyen
content: [caption id="attachment_123615" align="alignnone" width="601"] Biology teacher Tara Verekyen sits in her classroom full of students during Flex. Photo: Daniella Maydan.[/caption] This is the sixth installment of Coffee Chats, where The Paly Voice gets to know staff members over a cup of coffee. The Paly Voice sat down with new Palo Alto High School biology teacher Tara Verekyen, and discussed her interests and her journey to becoming a teacher over a medium iced coffee. While this is Verekyen’s 7th year teaching biology, she began her academic journey with an interest in anthropology and was fascinated by evolution and the way in which organs evolve over time. “I wanted to pursue anthropology because I like having a deeper insight into the biology behind human evolution and human origins," Verekyen said. "However, I found through volunteering as a tutor and volunteering at a museum that I enjoyed working in science education. When I graduated, I decided to put my interest of science together with my interest of teaching, and start a post-bachelor teaching program." Verekyen moved to the Bay Area from Arizona in search of a change, as well as a way to be closer to family. She currently enjoys working with her stepmother, AP Statistics teacher Misha Stempel, at Paly. "It's awesome, but it's kind of crazy," Verekyen said. "We [Verekyen and Stempel] drive in to work together and we wave to each other in meetings. It's great!" According to Stempel, it's great to see her stepdaughter at Paly because she is able to reconnect with her as well as reminisce about old times. "It's just kind of cool because when she was younger and she and her sister would get out of school they would come to Paly and draw on the chalkboards," Stempel said.  "I still have those pictures they drew for me back then so having  her here now is really cool. It's fun catching up with her and being a part of her life." According to Verekyen, she appreciates the environment at Paly and enjoys interacting with the students. “It's awesome, there is so much support here and so many great things going on on campus that I didn't see at my other schools,” Verekyen said. Verekyen believes that biology is an important class to take in high school. "I love teaching freshman biology because I think it sets a really good foundation for what students are going to need later on in high school and in college" Verekyen said. Other than teaching, Verekyen enjoys traveling and advises her students to consider studying abroad when in college. "It really gives unique perspective and helps you to see how your major connects to the world in a more authentic way," Verkeyen said. To students planning on pursuing biology, Verekyen encourages curiosity. “My advice for students that pursue biology is to find a topic that you really love and start exploring it, see how you can use that passion to solve modern day challenges or help people," Verekyen said. "And question everything. Ask a lot of questions. Question it all."
excerpt: The Paly Voice sat down with Palo Alto High School Biology teacher Tara Verekyen, and discussed her interests and her journey to becoming a teacher over a medium iced coffee.
author: Daniella Maydan

title: Groundbreaking Homecoming dance is groundbreakingly average
content: Palo Alto Homecoming traditions continue to be formed and broken: After a historical dance last year, the Paly Associated Student Body and Gunn Student Executive Council hosted the first-ever joint Homecoming dance last Saturday. Despite the exciting intermingling between Paly and Gunn students, this year’s dance was also plagued with lengthy lines, minimal food and general confusion. The dance took place in two gyms at Henry M. Gunn High School, and students were free to walk from one building to another to dance or play games such as ping pong or foosball with friends. While the buildings provided ample space, the hallway between the two had a bottleneck effect due to its small width and the large number of students constantly passing through.  The real trouble, however, began outside the front door. Several lines of roughly 2,100 students wound their way down to the parking lot, blocking cars. Many students were confused as to which line they had to stand in, and the process took over an hour for some. According to Paly Assistant Principal Kathleen Laurence, ticket takers aimed to spend five seconds admitting each student into the dance. “We actually finished getting kids in seven minutes faster than we thought possible,” Laurence said. [caption id="attachment_125027" align="alignright" width="438"] Students stand in a line stretching from the gym entrance into the parking lot to enter the dance. "Waiting in line for nearly an hour ended up taking up a significant portion of the dance itself," senior Alix Westgaard said. Photo: Aidan Maese-Czeropski.[/caption] While long waits are understandable, administration breathalyzed every single student, which was a waste of time. An alternative would be to breathalyze one in five or one in 10 students, saving time and still preventing underage drinking. Furthermore, the lack of signs made it so many people were unaware if they were in line to purchase tickets or enter the dance, and administration did little to prevent students from cutting in line. Some students spent over one third of their allotted time standing in line, yet the dance was not extended.  When I finally entered the gymnasium one hour after I arrived, I was eager to eat. Unfortunately, nearly all the food had been consumed by the time I arrived, save for a bowl of colorful chips and salsa. Attendants occasionally brought out stacks of cookies or chocolate covered strawberries, and while they were delicious, they rarely lasted long. With thousands of students attending the dance, ASB and SEC should have expected the food to be quickly devoured and prepared accordingly. The long lines and minimal food were partially compensated by enjoyable music and dancing: the most anticipated part of Homecoming was, as always, the dance floor. The DJ accepted student song requests and played a large variety of genres that were generally danceable. Iridescent lights and images of stars flashed across the walls, and most students were receptive to the music. Reconnecting with friends from other schools and meeting new people was both easy and encouraged, on and off the dance floor. The dance featured entertaining games, including ping pong and foosball, as well as photo booths and a caricature artist. However, these areas remained extremely crowded. Increasing the number of ping pong tables from the two present would have allowed more people to take part in the fun. Special effects such as lights and banners outside the dance room were also minimal. This itself was fine, as streamers don’t necessarily entertain; however, students were promised extra amenities in exchange for an inexpensive venue so the rooms felt almost bare. Paly senior Alix Westgaard says that while Homecoming was an enjoyable experience, it could have been planned much better. "I think the challenge of having so many people attending the same venue needed to be addressed," Westgaard said. "There wasn't enough space for all the cars picking up students and there weren't enough entrances to the dance, causing a very long line. In the future, they could try to stagger the homecomings so they occurred on different weekends or try to find a different location for Paly's homecoming. Leaving the parking lot after the dance also took forty-five minutes." Homecoming 2016 wasn’t entirely "bad." But when sprinting to the food table to grab a snickerdoodle or two before they run out is one of the dance’s high points, you know the night didn’t live up to its potential.
excerpt: Despite the exciting intermingling between Paly and Gunn students, this year’s Homecoming dance was plagued with lengthy lines, minimal food and general confusion.
author: Aidan Maese-Czeropski

title: Editorial: The Paly Voice endorses Collins, Caswell and DiBrienza
content:
With the upcoming election, three Palo Alto Unified School District Board of Education seats will be up for grabs. Five candidates have been competing for the opening positions, two of whom are incumbents Heidi Emberling and Melissa Baten Caswell; the newcomers include Todd Collins, Jay Blas Jacob Cabrera and Jennifer DiBrienza. The Paly Voice staff and editors took time to research and evaluate the various candidates and their positions on topics ranging from the homework policy to budget deficit and the conduct of teachers on campus. Additionally, members of staff spent time attending forums with all five candidates present and interviewing the incumbents on current issues. After much deliberation as a staff, The Paly Voice has decided to endorse Todd Collins, incumbent Melissa Baten Caswell and Jennifer DiBrienza. 

Todd Collins: The Fiscally Responsible Candidate

[caption id="attachment_122806" align="alignleft" width="272"] Todd Collins, a candidate for school board, referenced his experiences serving on various committees to voice his perspective. Photo: Zahra Muzaffar[/caption] Collins, a private investor, has spent time engaged with the board, but brings a new perspective that current conditions warrant. Over the years he has spent time involved in various school board committees such as the Citizens’ Oversight Committee of a school bond program and the school board’s Enrollment Management Advisory Committee over the 2015-16 school year. Collins earns our support because of his continued vocal concerns regarding the several million dollar budget deficit. While other candidates have acknowledged the issue, he has been the only one to recognize that innovation is contingent upon the availability of funds. Collins supports new pathways and programs, but doesn’t consider them to be feasible given current financial conditions. Collins not only has the financial background, but is an asset because of his attention to detail and exposure to the board's past finances via various committees. Additionally, in keeping with his recommendations following his time on EMAC, Collins concurs with The Paly Voice staff in standing against the creation of new schools within the district due to declining enrollment in elementary schools the past few years. Collins persistently emphasizes the need for data-driven decision making, whether it be concerning the homework policy or the continuation of the current teacher evaluation system. Collins values resiliency, an integral part of the learning process, and wants to see PAUSD students “experience and overcome failure." Melissa Baten Caswell: The Experienced Incumbent Caswell will be completing her second term, and while outside of the norm, electing her to a third this coming November will benefit the Palo Alto community because of her extensive knowledge regarding administrative procedures. She has previously served as board president and has experience serving on various school specific Parent Teacher Association councils. [caption id="attachment_122810" align="alignright" width="302"] Melissa Baten Caswell, who has completed two terms on the school board, acknowledged areas of improvement and strengths of the current school board. Photo: Zahra Muzaffar[/caption] Caswell is one of few current members to strongly support student voice, recognizing that the zero period controversy at Gunn High School was a top-down decision. Caswell’s focus on garnering the creativity within our teachers and providing ample resources and time to allow them to innovate within the classroom resonates with The Paly Voice. As students we benefit from inventive programs, many of which have been implemented during her time on the board. Flipped classrooms, blended learning and programs such as Social Justice and Advanced Authentic Research allow for individualized learning experiences, enhancing our development as 21st century learners. Caswell displays some of the best features of the current board. She not only recognizes its shortcomings, but actively works to provide efficient solutions.  During school board forums she has addressed that the mission of the district is to educate its students and that the "quality of the teachers preempts everything." A pragmatic decision maker, Caswell advocates for an improved system of mental health services while acknowledging the district’s limitations. Incumbents, including Caswell, have been criticized for their lack of transparency and mismanagement in regards to finances and dealing with the Office of Civil Rights over the past few years. However, Caswell has remained consistent in her stances and takes the time to deliberate before outlining her position. Although she voiced her support for the teacher pay raise, Caswell is in favor of aggressive measures to reduce the deficit. Jennifer DiBrienza: The Needed Educator [caption id="attachment_122799" align="alignleft" width="263"] Jennifer Dibrienza relied on her experiences as an Educational Consultant to provide explanations for her various stances. Photo: Zahra Muzaffar[/caption] DiBrienza, a teacher and staff developer for primary schools, embodies the necessary background for a seat on the school board. Previously, DiBrienza was an educational consultant and has served on Ohlone Elementary School’s site council. While the achievement gap and inequity in education have recently become synonymous with PAUSD, DiBrienza was one of few to continuously reference the importance of equitable access to the choices available at our schools. DiBrienza’s experience within the classroom will provide an integral perspective that the school board has been lacking. Hopefully, she will help the board as a whole to recognize how each decision truly impacts the experience of a student. Acknowledging the Competition Cabrera and Emberling have put up valiant efforts and their desire to aid the district’s students should be recognized. Cabrera offers the grass-roots perspective and should be applauded for his campaign based entirely upon small donations. He offers bold ideas that would add value to innovations within any district. Similarly, Emberling’s efforts over the past years have not been forgotten. Her emphasis on the best practices for each individual school is worth noting. Cabrera, despite his ingenuity, has drawbacks; he has focused his efforts on emphasizing respectable beliefs against the current system of politics reliant upon money. He strays away from providing adequate solutions to the specific problems faced by our community. Emberling, despite her time on the board, does not have a consistent stance on issues that we feel are pertinent. She has contributed to the ambiguous statements that prevent the current board from efficiently making decisions. While many of us as minors cannot express our support via an actual vote, our hope is to garner support for those who we believe will serve our best interests as students and community members. Their actions and decisions will outlive our legacies as Palo Alto High School students, but the election of Collins, Caswell and DiBrienza will ensure the best experience for future PAUSD students.
excerpt: After much deliberation as a staff, The Paly Voice has decided to endorse Todd Collins, incumbent Melissa Baten Caswell and Jennifer DiBrienza.
author: The Paly Voice

title: Spirit Week 2016 in review
content:
Spirit Week at Palo Alto High School is nothing short of spectacular. From thunderous rallies that can be heard from Stanford University, to awe-inspiring floats put together in a short week's time, each year brings something new and exciting to the famous tradition. With outrageous outfits and tight competitions, Spirit Week is regarded by many students as their favorite week of the school year. The Paly Voice takes a look at what made Spirit Week 2016 so memorable.

<iframe src="https://cdn.knightlab.com/libs/timeline3/latest/embed/index.html?source=1Ox71NOoGxroDm0MNZ9P4UyeOlBJ3pdDolM1hBEcLn6A&font=Default&lang=en&initial_zoom=2&height=750" width="125%" height="750" frameborder="0"></iframe>
excerpt: Spirit Week at Palo Alto High School is nothing short of spectacular. The Paly Voice takes a look at what made Spirit Week 2016 so memorable.
author: Maya Reuven

title: Spirit Dances 2016
content:
Palo Alto High School Spirit Week came to a close with the after school rally on Friday. Per Paly tradition, the rally featured a Float and Spirit Dance from each grade. Additionally, several teachers performed an encore to the annual Teacher Spirit Dance.

Click on the link to view the full dances and photos of each float.

<iframe style="border: none;" src="https://social.shorthand.com/thepalyvoice/embed/jgdHli1J1T" width="100%" height="500px"></iframe>
excerpt: Palo Alto High School Spirit Week came to a close with the after school rally on Friday. Per Paly tradition, the rally featured a Float and Spirit Dance from each grade. Additionally, several teachers performed an encore to the annual Teacher Spirit Dance.
author: Zahra Muzaffar

title: Final Spirit Week score results
content: On the final day of Spirit Week, the underclassmen and juniors showed their Paly pride by dressing in green and white while the seniors wore camouflage gear. Spirit Week then finished off with the exhibition of each grade's dances and floats Friday after school. The junior class claimed the victory in float in a senior upset. Despite placing second in float, the senior class finished 1st in dance and topped the overall rankings. After a strong dance performance, the sophomore class earned 2nd place, leaving them in 3rd overall. Finally, after a strong effort, the freshmen finished 4th overall.
excerpt: Despite a junior upset over the seniors on the float, the seniors were victorious overall. The juniors, sophomores and freshmen placed second, third and fourth, respectively.
author: Aidan Maese-Czeropski

title: Football falls to Los Gatos in Homecoming game
content: [caption id="attachment_124938" align="alignnone" width="750"] Palo Alto High School senior wide receiver Nick Smallwood prepares for the snap. Paly would go on to lose to Los Gatos High School, 35-6 on Friday night at home. Photo: Jackson Doerr.[/caption] The Palo Alto High School Vikings football team (3-5, 2-2) is fighting for a spot in the De Anza league playoffs after losing its homecoming game against the Los Gatos Wildcats (4-3, 3-0), 35-6, last night on the Paly football field. The game was an ordeal for the Vikings, who struggled to put the Wildcats' strong offense on hold, throughout the entirety of the game. Just five minutes into the game, the Wildcats broke through the Paly defense to score the first touchdown of the game. The rest of the first quarter was a scoreless standoff, and the ball did not leave Paly's half. In the second quarter, Los Gatos gained 96 yards in ten plays over the course of two minutes and 12 seconds, and added another Wildcat touchdown to the scoreboard. On the very next play, a player from each team was ejected for personal fouls, including Paly junior offensive lineman Bryant Jefferson. Viking head coach Danny Sullivan said he disagrees with the call and he believes that the skirmish was not grounds for ejection of either player. "It was just an overreaction to the play," Sullivan said. "I was looking at it the whole time and I don't think anybody should have gotten ejected, including their kid." Los Gatos would go on to score twice in the 3rd and once in the 4th, bringing the score to 35-0. But with three minutes left in the game, Paly was able to get a touchdown, preventing the Wildcats from securing a shutout win. According to Sullivan, Paly struggled with performing smaller plays. "We started moving the ball but we hit a wall," Sullivan said. "Simple execution on little things is the difference between the two scores so we've got to get better at doing that." According to Sullivan, the Vikings will continue to focus on working the kinks out of their play. "It's just doing the fine tuning that we really have to focus on," Sullivan said. "We've gotten so much better over the course of the season and we're only going to keep getting better." Sullivan said the season is far from over, and the Vikings are in competition for a spot in the playoffs. "We're playing for a playoff spot in these next two weeks," Sullivan said. "Next week is a bye week. We need to get a couple things neatened up and then it's off to Mountain View." According to Sullivan, the Week Nine bye is a blessing in disguise. "We were looking at it and Week Nine looks like the worst time for a bye," Sullivan said. "[However,] It comes at a perfect time because we need to jump back on the horse." The Vikings will fight for a spot in the playoffs against the Mountain View High School Spartans (6-3, 3-2) at 7:00pm on Nov. 4 at Mountain View.
excerpt: The Palo Alto High School Vikings football team (3-5, 2-2) are fighting for a spot in the De Anza league playoffs after losing their homecoming game against the Los Gatos Wildcats (4-3, 3-0) 35-6 last night on the Paly football field.
author: William Sallomi

title: Video: Spirit Week Day 5 ends with dazzling performances
content: The Paly Voice documented the fifth and final day of Palo Alto High School's Spirit Week. "Paly Spirit Day" featured the exciting "Hula Hoop" race at the lunch rally, as well as the unveiling of class floats and class dance performances after school Final scores for Spirit Week will be released today during the Homecoming dance at Gunn High School. Check The Paly Voice for more updates on Spirit Week 2016 under the new Spirit Week tab. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2mTWglu122M&feature=youtu.be
excerpt: The Paly Voice documented the fifth and final day of Palo Alto High School's Spirit Week. "Paly Spirit Day" featured the exciting "Hula Hoop" race at the lunch rally, as well as the unveiling of class floats and class dance performances after school
author: Julia Qiao
